title: If Statement
body: The if statement is the fundamental decision-making statement. Specific code is executed based on whether the condition is met or not. Both the true and false outcomes can result in another process, decision, or outcome.

title: If Statement Example
body:
Consider the following statement:

Persons of age 14 and under are in the child life stage, while persons older than 14 are in the adult life stage.

In a logic tree, this statement is two branches: one representing the condition for being considered a child, and another for the condition of being an adult. If we decide to focus on the first branch where the condition is related to being a child, we have a conditional statement at our flowchart decision point, Age <= 14.

If the person is 14 or younger, then the conditional statement is True and the output will be child. If the person is older than 14, the condition is False and the output will be adult.

The pseudocode of this process can either be in terms of a boolean output, i.e., child is either True or False, or text output, i.e., the life stage is either child or adult, depending on the purpose of the algorithm.

title: Target 1.1: Eradicate extreme poverty
body: Consider the target ”eradicate extreme poverty”:

title: If Statement pt. 3
body: Read the pseudocode out loud to help you understand this type of representation of an algorithm!

title: Indicators for Target 1
body: Although the target provides us with a resolution and some indication of a measure, its indicator gives us measurable parameters:

title: New Block Title
body:
In order to calculate how we are progressing in terms of target 1.1 we need to determine their sex, age, employment status, geographical location, and whether they are above or below the international poverty line.

However, indicator 1.1.1 is also related to indicator 1.2.1 (”reduce poverty by 50%”), and 10.1.1 and 10.1.2 from goal 10 (“reduce inequality within and among countries”). This means that if any of these indicators change, any or all of the other indicators may change as well.

title: If-Else Statement Example
body:
Consider the following statement:

Persons of age 14 and under are in the child life stage, while persons older than 14 but younger than 65 are in the adult life stage, and persons of the age 65 and older are in the pensioner life stage.

Our logic tree now has three branches relating to conditional statements on the age of being considered a child, adult, or pensioner.

Our flowchart now has two decision points. First, we decide if the person is a child or not a child. Then, since being a child has already been ruled out based on the first condition, we simply decide if the person is an adult or not an adult.

If the person is neither a child nor an adult, then the person can only be a pensioner.

title: Target 1.2: Reduce poverty by at least 50%
displayTitle: Target 1.2: Reduce poverty by at least 50%
body: The target text reads as follows:

title: Nested If Statements
body: If the statement changes to include another condition that overarches all other statements, then we need nested if statements. This is simply when an if statement is placed inside of another statement. We use nested if statements when we must decide on a combination of conditions before deciding the next action or final output.

title: New Block Title
body: And its corresponding indicators are:

title: New Block Title
body:
We’ve already seen the relationship between indicators 1.2.1 and 1.1.1. However, indicator 1.2.2 is slightly different in that each country has its own measure of multidimensional poverty. The measure depends on the context and issues affecting poverty in that country, as well as available data.

Considering the global and South African Multidimensional Poverty Indices (MPIs) in the below figures, we can see that measuring poverty is complex because it is dependent on health, education, living standards, as well as economic activity.

title: Target 1.3: Implement social protection systems
body: The target text reads as follows:

title: New Block Title
body: And its corresponding indicator is:

title: New Block Title
body:
There is also a causal relationship between indicator 1.3.1, the mobilisation of resources to implement policies through governmental spending to end poverty (indicator 1.a.2), and household (and other expenditures) on health (indicators 3.8.1 and 3.8.2).

This relationship indicates that if governments were to spend more money on social protection, fewer people will have fewer expenses when it comes to health coverage. Also, if more people are employed, with greater incomes, more people will be protected and fewer people will be classified as living in poverty.

title: New Block Title
body: Target 1.5 and its indicators are related to many of the other SDGs. Due to these complexities, the Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction was chosen to simplify the interactions between the goals relating to environmental, economic, and social disasters.
